lesson.name: Lesson 9.5 Teacher Guide: Quadratic Equations with Irrational Solutions

page.title: 9.5.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative

This lesson serves two main purposes: to reiterate that some solutions to quadratic equations are irrational, and to give students the tools to express those solutions exactly and succinctly.

Students recall that the radical symbol \((\sqrt{\;\;})\) can be used to denote the positive square root of a number. Many quadratic equations have a positive and a negative solution, and up until this point, students have been writing them separately. For example, the solutions of \(x^2=49\) are \(x=7\) and \(x=-7\). Here, students are introduced to the plus-minus symbol \((\pm)\) as a way to express both solutions (for example, \(x= \pm 7\)).

Students also briefly recall the meanings of rational and irrational numbers. (They will have a more thorough review later in the unit.) They see that sometimes the solutions are expressions that involve a rational number and an irrational number—for example, \(x=\pm \sqrt{8}+3\). While this is a compact, exact, and efficient way to express irrational solutions, it is not always easy to intuit the size of the solutions just by looking at the expressions. Students make sense of these solutions by finding their decimal approximations and by solving the equations by graphing. The work here gives students opportunities to reason quantitatively and abstractly.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Coordinate and compare (orally and in writing) solutions to quadratic equations obtained by completing the square and those obtained by graphing.
  • Explain that the "plus-minus" symbol is used to represent both square roots of a number and that the square root notation expresses only the positive square root.
  • Use radical and "plus-minus" symbols to express solutions to quadratic equations.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Use the radical and "plus-minus" symbols to represent solutions to quadratic equations.
  • Explain why the plus-minus symbol is used when solving quadratic equations by finding square roots.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A8(A) solve quadratic equations having real solutions by factoring, taking square roots, completing the square, and applying the quadratic formula.

Partial coverage: Lesson provides content that covers part of this TEKS. The parts that are covered have been underlined.

A11(A) simplify numerical radical expressions involving square roots.

Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 9.5.1: Roots of Squares
  • 9.5.2: Solutions Written as Square Roots
    • 9.5.2: Self Check
    • 9.5.2: Additional Resources
  • 9.5.3: Finding Irrational Solutions by Completing the Square
    • 9.5.3: Self Check
    • 9.5.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.5.4: Finding Exact Solutions

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 9.5.5: Practice.

Required Materials

  • Graphing technology

Required Preparation

  • Acquire devices that can run Desmos (recommended) or other graphing technology. It is ideal if each student has their own device.

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson.
  • Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in "math talk" and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards.

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson:

Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary
  • completing the square
  • rational number
  • irrational number

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their intellectual humility.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • Watch Your Words
  • V Is for Vulnerability

You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Intellectual Humility from Character Lab.

page.title: 9.5.1: Roots of Squares
page.contents:
Warm Up (5 minutes)

This warm up reminds students that we can use the notation \(\sqrt{A}\) to express the side length of a square with area \(A\) and that the value of \(\sqrt{A}\) may not be a whole number or a fraction.

To find the area of a tilted square, students might choose different strategies:

  • Decompose the square and rearrange the parts into rectangles.
  • Enclose the tilted square with another square that is on the grid and subtract the areas of the extra triangles.
  • Use the Pythagorean Theorem to calculate the squared value of the side length.

Launch

Display the entire task for all to see. Give students quiet think time. Select students to share their responses and how they reasoned about the side length and area of each square.

Student Activity

Here are some squares whose vertices are on a grid.

Find the area and the side length of each square.

  1. What is the area of Graph A?

Answer: 9
9 square units

  1. What is the side length of Graph A?

Answer: 3
3 units

  1. What is the area of Graph B?

Answer: 2
2 square units

  1. What is the side length of Graph B?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \(\sqrt{2}\) units

  1. What is the area of Graph C?

Answer: 10
10 square units

  1. What is the side length of Graph C?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \(\sqrt{10}\) units

Activity Synthesis

Invite students to share their solutions. It is not essential to discuss how students found the area. What is important is that students recall that we can use the square root notation \(\sqrt{9}\) to refer to the side length of a square with area 9 square units and that \(\sqrt{9}=3\). When the area is 2 or 10 square units, the square root of each number is not a whole number or a fraction, but we can write \(\sqrt{2}\) and \(\sqrt{10}\) rather than writing their decimal approximations.

Remind students that any positive number has two square roots because there are two numbers (one positive and one negative) that, when squared, give that number. Also remind students that the \(\sqrt{\;\;}\) symbol refers only to the positive square root of a number. In this context, if \(s\) is the side length of a square and \(A\) its area, we can describe the relationship between the two quantities as \(s=\sqrt{A}\) because only positive side lengths make sense.

page.title: 9.5.2: Solutions Written as Square Roots
page.contents:
Activity (15 minutes)

This activity introduces the use of the \(\pm\) notation as a simple way to express the two square roots of a number. Students solve several simple equations by finding square roots and express their solutions using the notation.

Students also see that sometimes the solutions are not rational numbers and can be expressed exactly using the radical notation rather than using their decimal approximations. For example, the solutions to \(x^2=24\) can be written as \(x= \pm \sqrt{24}\) rather than \(x \approx \pm 4.9\) and the solutions to \((x-3)^2=24\) can be written as \(x= \pm \sqrt{24}+3\) instead of \(x \approx \pm 4.9+3\).

Launch

Remind students that we have seen that some quadratic equations have two solutions. Take the equation \(x^2=25\), for example. For the equation to be true, \(x\) can be 5 and -5 because \(5^2=25\) and \((-5)^2=25\). We have been writing the solutions as: \(x=5\) and \(x=-5\). Explain that a shorter way to convey the same information is by writing \(x= \pm 5\).

Student Activity

Solve each equation. Use the notation when appropriate and express radicals in simplest form.

  1. \(x^2-13=-12\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \(x= \pm 1\)

  1. \((x-6)^2=0\)

Answer: 6
\(x = 6\)

  1. \(x^2+9=0\)

Answer: No real solution

  1. \(x^2=18\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \(x= \pm 3 \sqrt{2}\)

  1. \(x^2+1=18\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \(x= \pm \sqrt{17}\)

  1. \((x+1)^2=18\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \(x=-1 pm 3 \sqrt{2}\) (or equivalent)

Video: Solving Quadratics with Square Roots

Watch the following video to learn more about equations with solutions that are square roots.



Anticipated Misconceptions

When using \(\pm\) the notation for the first time, some students may struggle to remember that it shows a number and its opposite. Encourage those students to continue writing their answers both ways in this lesson to reinforce the meaning of the new notation. Show students how both solutions work in the original equation by checking the answers.

Some students may still struggle to understand the meaning of the square root. Watch for students who evaluate a square root by dividing by 2. Ask these students what the square root of 9 is. If this does not convince students that dividing by two is the incorrect operation, demonstrate that we call 3 a square root of 9 because \(3 \cdot 3=9\).

Activity Synthesis

Invite students to share their solutions. Record and display the solutions for all to see. Discuss any disagreements, if there are any.

Draw students' attention to the last three sets of solutions, which are irrational. Ask students to recall the meaning of rational numbers and irrational numbers. Remind students that a rational number is a fraction or its opposite, for example: 12, -7, \(\frac18\), \(-\frac18\), 90.38, or 0.005. Irrational numbers are numbers that are not rational, for example: \(\sqrt{2}\), \(\pi\), and \(\sqrt{10}\). (Students will have more opportunities to review and classify rational and irrational numbers later in the unit, so for now, it suffices that they remember that an irrational number is a number that is not rational.)

Highlight that when the solution is irrational, the most concise way to write an exact solution is, for example, \(x= \pm \sqrt{18}-1\). Writing this in decimal form only allows us to write an approximate solution. For example, in this case, 3.24 and -5.24 are approximate solutions.

Then, display the variations in writing the solutions to \((x+1)^2=18\) for all to see. Discuss how they are all different ways of writing the same two solutions.

  • \(x= \pm \sqrt{18}-1\)
  • \(x= \sqrt{18}-1\) and \(x=- \sqrt{18}-1\)
  • \(x=-1 \pm \sqrt{18}\)
  • \(x=-1+ \sqrt{18}\) and \(x=-1- \sqrt{18}\)

Students will likely need review on simplifying radicals. Highlight that simplifying a radical does not mean that it is rational. So \(\sqrt{18}\) is irrational and so is \(3 \sqrt{2}\).

9.5.2: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

Solve \(x^2-3=19\).

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(x=-4\), \(x=4\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Be sure to add 3 to each side before taking the square root. The answer is \(x= \pm \sqrt{22}\).

\(x= \pm \sqrt{19}+3\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Be sure to add 3 to each side before taking the square root. The answer is \(x= \pm \sqrt{22}\).

\(x= \pm \sqrt{22}\).

That’s correct! Check yourself: First add 3 to both sides, then take the square root, remembering the positive and negative solutions.

\(x= \pm 22\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Be sure to take the square root of both sides of the equation. The answer is \(x= \pm \sqrt{22}\).

9.5.2: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Solving Quadratics with Radical Solutions

When solving quadratic equations, it is important to remember that:

  • Any positive number has two square roots, one positive and one negative, because there are two numbers that can be squared to make that number. (For example, \(6^2 \)and \((-6)^2\) both equal 36, so 6 and -6 are both square roots of 36.)
  • The square root symbol \((\sqrt{\;\;})\) can be used to express the positive square root of a number. For example, the square root of 36 is 6, but it can also be written as \(\sqrt{36}\) because \(\sqrt{36} \cdot \sqrt{36}=36\).
  • To express the negative square root of a number, say 36, we can write -6 or \(-\sqrt{36}\).
  • When a number is not a perfect square, for example, 40, we can express its square roots by writing 40 and \(-\sqrt{40}\).

How could we write the solutions to an equation like \((x+4)^2=11\)? This equation is saying, “something squared is 11.” To make the equation true, that something must be \(\sqrt{11}\) or \(-\sqrt{11}\).

We can write:

\(x+4= \sqrt{11}\)      or      \(x+4= - \sqrt{11}\)

\(x=-4+ \sqrt{11}\)      or      \(x=-4+- \sqrt{11}\)

A more compact way to write the two solutions to the equation is: \(x=-4 \pm \sqrt{11}\).

Try It: Solving Quadratics with Radical Solutions

Solve \((x-2)^2=17\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to solve this quadratic equation:

Step 1
Make sure the quadratic is isolated on one side.
\((x-2)^2=17\)

Step 2
Take the square root of both sides.
\(\sqrt{(x-2)^2}= \pm \sqrt{17}\)

Step 3
Simplify.
\(x-2= \pm \sqrt{17}\)

Step 4
Solve the equation. For this problem, add 2 to each side.
\( x-2+2=2 \pm \sqrt{17}\)

Step 5
Simplify.
\(x=2- \sqrt{17}\), \(x=2+ \sqrt{17}\)

page.title: 9.5.3: Finding Irrational Solutions by Completing the Square
page.contents:
Activity (15 minutes)

This activity allows students to integrate several skills and ideas they have learned so far: solving quadratic equations by graphing and by completing the square, using the \(\pm\) notation, and expressing solutions both approximately and exactly (using the square root symbol). In solving the equations algebraically and using the notations to express and verify solutions, students practice attending to precision.

The last equation may be challenging for some students as it involves fractions and messier-looking solutions. It is not essential that all students get to this equation. They will have a chance to encounter more complicated equations and solutions in upcoming lessons.

Launch

Display the equation \(x^2+6x+7=0\) for all to see. Ask students if they could solve it by rewriting it in factored form. (The expression cannot be rewritten in factored form.) Remind students that they know how to solve any equation by completing the square, which would give exact solutions. They also know how to solve by graphing, which would give approximate solutions.

Arrange students in groups of two and provide access to graphing technology. One partner should find exact solutions by completing the square and the other should find approximate solutions by graphing. Partners should confirm that the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph (or the zeros of the function represented by the graph) approximate the exact solutions obtained algebraically. Ask partners to switch roles for each equation.

Student Activity

Here is an example of an equation being solved by graphing and by completing the square.

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}+6 x+7 &=0 \\ x^{2}+6 x+9 &=2 \\ (x+3)^{2} &=2 \\ x+3 &=\pm \sqrt{2} \\ x &=-3 \pm \sqrt{2} \end{aligned}\)

Verify: \(\sqrt{2}\) is approximately 1.414. So \(-3+ \sqrt{2} \approx -1.586\) and \(-3- \sqrt{2} \approx -4.414\).

For each equation, find the exact solutions by completing the square and the approximate solutions by graphing. Then, verify that the solutions found using the two methods are close. If you get stuck, refer back to the example.

  1. \(x^2+4x+1=0\)
  1. Find the exact solutions by completing the square.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}+4 x+1 &=0 \\ x^{2}+4 x &=-1 \\ x^{2}+4 x+4 &=-1+4 \\ x^{2}+4 x+4 &=3 \\ (x+2)^{2} &=3 \\ \sqrt{(x+2)^{2}} &=\sqrt{3} \\ x+2 &=\pm \sqrt{3} \\x&=-2 \pm \sqrt{3}\end{aligned}\)

  1. Graph the equation to find approximate solutions. 

Use the Desmos graphing tool or technology outside the course. 

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

  1. Are the solutions you found using the two methods close? 
  • Yes
  • No

Answer: Yes
Solutions were the same: \(x \approx -0.268\) and \(x \approx -3.732\).

  1. \(x^2−10x+18=0\)
  1. Find the exact solutions by completing the square.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}-10 x+18 &=0 \\ x^{2}-10 x &=-18 \\ x^{2}-10 x+25 &=-18+25 \\ x^{2}-10 x+25 &=7 \\ (x-5)^{2} &=7 \\ \sqrt{(x-5)^{2}} &=\sqrt{7} \\ x-5 &=\pm \sqrt{7} \\ x &=5 \pm \sqrt{7} \end{aligned}\)

  1. Graph the equation to find approximate solutions. 

Use the Desmos graphing tool or technology outside the course. 

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

  1. Are the solutions you found using the two methods close? 
  • Yes
  • No

Answer: Yes
Solutions were the same: \(x \approx 7.646\) and \(x \approx 2.354\).

  1. \(x^2+5x+\frac{1}{4}=0\)
  1. Find the exact solutions by completing the square.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: 

\(\begin{array}{rcl} x^{2}+5 x+\frac{1}{4} &=& 0 \\ x^{2}+5 x &=& -\frac{1}{4} \\ x^{2}+5 x+\left(\frac{5}{2}\right)^{2} &=& -\frac{1}{4}+\left(\frac{5}{2}\right)^{2} \\ x^{2}+5 x+\frac{25}{4} &=& -\frac{1}{4}+\frac{25}{4} \\ x^{2}+5 x+\frac{25}{4} &=& \frac{24}{4} \\ x^{2}+5 x+\frac{25}{4} &=& 6 \\ \left(x+\frac{5}{2}\right)^{2} &=& 6 \\ \sqrt{\left(x+\frac{5}{2}\right)^{2}} &=& \sqrt{6} \\ x+\frac{5}{2} &=& \pm \sqrt{6} \\ x &=& -\frac{5}{2} \pm \sqrt{6} \end{array}\)

  1. Graph the equation to find approximate solutions. 

Use the Desmos graphing tool or technology outside the course. 

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: 

  1. Are the solutions you found using the two methods close?
  • Yes
  • No

Answer: Yes
Solutions were the same: \(x \approx -4.949\) and \(x \approx -0.051\).

  1. \(x^2+\frac{8}{3}x+\frac{14}{9}=0\)
  1. Find the exact solutions by completing the square.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: 

\(\begin{array}{rcl} x^{2}+\frac{8}{3} x+\frac{14}{9} &=&0 \\ x^{2}+\frac{8}{3} x &=&-\frac{14}{9} \\ x^{2}+\frac{8}{3} x+\left(\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{8}{3}\right)^{2} &=&-\frac{14}{9}+\left(\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{8}{3}\right)^{2} \\ x^{2}+\frac{8}{3} x+\left(\frac{4}{3}\right)^{2} &=&-\frac{14}{9}+\left(\frac{4}{3}\right)^{2} \\ x^{2}+\frac{8}{3} x+\frac{16}{9} &=&-\frac{14}{9}+\frac{16}{9} \\ x^{2}+\frac{8}{3} x+\frac{16}{9} &=&\frac{2}{9} \\ \left(x+\frac{4}{3}\right)^{2} &=&\frac{2}{9} \\ \sqrt{\left(x+\frac{4}{3}\right)^{2}} &=&\sqrt{\frac{2}{9}} \\ x+\frac{4}{3} &=&\pm \frac{\sqrt{2}}{3} \\ x &=&-\frac{4}{3} \pm \frac{\sqrt{2}}{3} \end{array}\)

  1. Graph the equation to find approximate solutions. 

Use the Desmos graphing tool or technology outside the course. 

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: 

  1. Are the solutions you found using the two methods close? 
  • Yes
  • No

Answer: Yes
Solutions were the same: \(x \approx -0.862\) and \(x \approx -1.805\).

Student-Facing Extension

Are you ready for more?

What quadratic equation of the form \(ax^2+bx+c=0\) would have the solutions \(x=5− \sqrt{2}\) and \(x=5+ \sqrt{2}\)?

Answer: \(x^2−10x+23=0\)

Working backward, these are solutions to \((x−5)^2=2\). In standard form, this is \(x^2−10x+23=0\).

Activity Synthesis

Discuss any common struggles or common mistakes made when solving the equations. Then, invite students to reflect on the merits and challenges of solving by each method. Ask questions such as:

  • "What are some benefits of solving by graphing? What are some drawbacks?" (Benefits: It is quick and straightforward. It shows the solutions, or that there are no solutions, even when the equations involve fractions or very large numbers. Drawbacks: It does not give exact solutions. Some tools may require adjusting the graphing window quite a bit to see the solutions.)
  • "What are some benefits and drawbacks of solving by completing the square?" (Benefit: It can be used to find exact solutions to any equation. Drawbacks: It can be pretty time consuming. When the equations have fractions or very large or very small numbers, the calculations get complicated and may be prone to error.)

9.5.3: Self Check 

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

Which of the following are the solutions to \((x-2)^2=12\), rounded to the nearest thousandth?

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(x \approx -3.162, x \approx 3.162\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This is the rounded decimal for \(\pm \sqrt{10}\). Be sure to take the square root then add the 2. The correct answer is \(x \approx -1.464, x \approx 5.464\).

\(x \approx -1.464, x \approx 5.464\)

That's correct! Check yourself: First take the square root of 12, then add 2 to both sides. There are two solutions because of the plus-minus sign.

\(x=14\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: You must take the square root before adding 2. The correct answer is \(x \approx -1.464, x \approx 5.464\).

\(x \approx 3.162\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: There are two solutions because the plus-minus sign is needed after taking the square root. The correct answer is \(x \approx -1.464, x \approx 5.464\).

9.5.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Using the Calculator for Approximate Solutions

Let's look at the solutions to the equations from 9.5.2: Additional Resources:

A more compact way to write the two solutions to the equation \((x+4)^2=11\) is: \(x=-4 \pm \sqrt{11}\).

How large or small are those numbers? Are they positive or negative? We can use a calculator to compute the approximate values of both expressions:

\(-4+ \sqrt{11} \approx -0.683\) or \(-4- \sqrt{11} \approx -7.317\)

We can also approximate the solutions by graphing. The equation \((x+4)^2=11\) is equivalent to \((x+4)^2−11=0\), so we can graph the function \(y=(x+4)^2−11\) and find its zeros by locating the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph.

Try It: Using the Calculator for Approximate Solutions

Approximate the solutions to \(x=3 \pm \sqrt{19}\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to approximate the solutions:

Step 1
Write two expressions.
\(x=3+ \sqrt{19}, x=3- \sqrt{19}\)

Step 2
Use the calculator to approximate the solutions to three decimal places.
\(x \approx -1.359, x \approx 7.359\)

page.title: 9.5.4: Finding Exact Solutions
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)

The approximate solutions are given so students can check (using a calculator) if their exact solutions match.

Student Activity

For the equation \(x^2+14x= -46\), the approximate solutions are \(x \approx -8.732\) and \(x \approx -5.268\).

Find the exact solutions by completing the square. Show your reasoning.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}+14 x &=-46 \\ x^{2}+14 x+49 &=-46+49 \\ x^{2}+14 x+49 &=3 \\ (x+7)^{2} &=3 \\ \sqrt{(x+7)^{2}} &=\sqrt{3} \\ x+7 &=\pm \sqrt{3} \\ x &=-7 \pm \sqrt{3} \end{aligned}\)

Response to Student Thinking

More Chances

Students will have more opportunities to understand the mathematical ideas in this cool down, so there is no need to slow down or add additional work to the next lessons. Instead, use the results of this cool down to provide guidance for what to look for and emphasize over the next several lessons to support students in advancing their current understanding.

page.title: 9.5.5: Practice
page.contents:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.

  1. Solve each equation and write the solutions using the ± notation, then choose the correct solution from the list.
  1. \(x^2=144\)
  • \(x= \pm\; 144\)
  • \(x= \pm\; 72\)
  • \(x= \pm\; 12\)
  • \(x= \pm\; 24\)

Answer: \(x= \pm\; 12\)

  1. \(x^2=5\)
  • \(x= \pm\; \sqrt{5}\)
  • \(x= \pm\; 5\)
  • \(x= \pm\; \frac{5}{2}\)  
  • \( x= \pm\; \sqrt{10}\)

Answer: \(x= \pm\; \sqrt{5}\)

  1. \(4x^2=28\)
  • \(x= \pm\; \sqrt {\frac{7}{2}}\)
  • \( x= \pm\; 7\)
  • \(x= \pm\; \frac{7}{2}\)  
  • \(x= \pm\; \sqrt{7}\)

Answer: \(x= \pm\; \sqrt{7}\)

  1. \(x^2=\frac{25}{4}\)
  • \(x= \pm\; \frac{25}{4}\)
  • \(x= \pm\; \frac{5}{2}\)
  • \(x= \pm\; \frac{10}{2}\)
  • \(x= \pm\; \frac{5}{4}\)

Answer: \(x= \pm\; \frac{5}{2}\)

  1. \(2x^2=22\)
  • \(x= \pm\; \sqrt{\frac{11}{2}}\)
  • \(x= \pm\; 11\)
  • \(x= \pm\; \frac{11}{2}\)  
  • \(x= \pm\; \sqrt{11}\)

Answer: \(x= \pm\;\sqrt{11}\)

  1. \(7x^2=16\)
  • \(x= \pm\; \sqrt{\frac{16}{7}}\)
  • \(x= \pm\; 16\)
  • \(x= \pm\; 8\)  
  • \(x= \pm \;\frac {\sqrt{16}}{7}\)

Answer: \(x= \pm \;\sqrt{\frac{16}{7}}\)

  1. For each expression, choose an equivalent expression.
  1. \(10 \pm\sqrt{4}\)
  • -17 and 5
  • \(4+ \sqrt{2}\) and \(4- \sqrt{2}\)
  • 8 and 12
  • 3 and 5
  • \(4+ \sqrt{10}\) and \(4- \sqrt{10}\)

Answer: 8 and 12

  1. \(4 \pm\sqrt{10}\)
  • -17 and 5
  • \(4+ \sqrt{2}\) and \(4- \sqrt{2}\)
  • 8 and 12
  • 3 and 5
  • \(4+ \sqrt{10}\) and \(4- \sqrt{10}\)

Answer: \(4+ \sqrt{10}\) and \(4- \sqrt{10}\)

  1. \(\sqrt{16} \pm\sqrt{2}\)
  • -17 and 5
  • \(4+ \sqrt{2}\) and \(4- \sqrt{2}\)
  • 8 and 12
  • 3 and 5
  • \(4+ \sqrt{10}\) and \(4- \sqrt{10}\)

Answer: \(4+ \sqrt{2}\) and \(4- \sqrt{2}\)

  1. What is the difference between \(\sqrt{9}\) and the solutions to \(x^2=9\)?
  • \(\sqrt{9}\) is equal to 3, while \(x^2=9\) is equal to -3.
  • \(\sqrt{9}\) is equal to -3, while there are two numbers that make \(x^2=9\) true: 3 and -3.
  • \(\sqrt{9}\) is equal to 3, while there are two numbers that make \(x^2=9\) true: 3 and -3.
  • There is no difference; they are equal. 

Answer: \(\sqrt{9}\) is equal to 3, while there are two numbers that make \(x^2=9\) true: 3 and -3.

  1. Technology required. For each equation, find the exact solutions by completing the square and the approximate solutions by graphing. Then, verify that the solutions found using the two methods are close.
  1. Solve the equation \(x^2+10x+8=0\) by completing the square. Select two exact solutions.
  • \(x= -5+ \sqrt{17}\)
  • \(x=5+ \sqrt{17}\)
  • \(x=5- \sqrt{17}\)
  • \(x= -5- \sqrt{17}\)

Answer: \(x= -5+ \sqrt{17}\), \(x= -5- \sqrt{17}\)

  1. Choose the graph that best represents the equation \(x^2+10x+8=0\).

Answer: . 

  1. Are the solutions and the graph for the equation \(x^2+10x+8=0\) similar? 
  • They are not similar. 
  • They are similar because the solutions are close. 
  • They are not similar because the square root of a number is always positive.
  • They are similar because the square root of a number is always positive.

Answer: They are similar because the solutions are close. 
\(-5- \sqrt{17} \approx -9.123\) and \(-5+ \sqrt{17} \approx -0.877\).

  1. Answer the following questions about \(x^2-4x-11=0\).
  1. Solve the equation \(x^2-4x-11=0\) by completing the square. Select two exact solutions.
  • \(x=-2+ \sqrt{15}\)
  • \(x=2+ \sqrt{15}\)
  • \(x=2- \sqrt{15}\)
  • \(x=-2- \sqrt{15}\)

Answer: \(x=2+ \sqrt{15}\), \(x=2-\sqrt{15}\)

  1. Choose the graph that best represents the equation \(x^2-4x-11=0\).    
  1.  

Answer: . 

  1. Are the solutions and the graph for the equation \(x^2-4x-11=0\) similar? 
  • They are similar because the solutions are close. 
  • They are not similar because the square root of a number is always positive.
  • They are not similar. 
  • They are similar because the square root of a number is always positive.

Answer: They are similar because the solutions are close. 
\(2-\sqrt{15} \approx -1.873\) and \(2+ \sqrt{15} \approx 5.873\).

page.title: 9.5.6: Lesson Synthesis
page.contents:
When solving quadratic equations, it is important to remember that:

  • Any positive number has two square roots, one positive and one negative, because there are two numbers that can be squared to make that number. (For example, \(6^2\) and \((-6)^2\) both equal 36, so 6 and -6 are both square roots of 36.)
  • The square root symbol \((\sqrt{\;\;})\) can be used to express the positive square root of a number. For example, the square root of 36 is 6, but it can also be written as \(\sqrt{36}\) because \(\sqrt{36} \cdot \sqrt{36}=36\).
  • To express the negative square root of a number, say 36, we can write -6 or \(- \sqrt{36}\).
  • When a number is not a perfect square (for example, 40), we can express its square roots by writing \(\sqrt{40}\) and \(- \sqrt{40}\).
